title: Zigzag Journeys in Europe: Vacation Rambles in Historic Lands
author: Butterworth, Hezekiah
snippet: The Class entered Rouen after a series of short, zigzag journeys,partly in coaches and partly on foot, going leisurely from town totown through roads that presented to view continuous landscapes ofshining orchards, ripening gardens, and resplendent poppy-fields;stopping at Amiens, the birthplace of Peter the Hermit, meeting hereand there a ruin, and finding everywhere the connecting historicallinks between the present and the past.

title: Zigzag Journeys in Europe: Vacation Rambles in Historic Lands
author: Butterworth, Hezekiah
snippet: But the thought of the stranger on coming to Rouen isless associated with its history under the sea-kings of the North, theNorman dukes and the English invaders, than with the hard fate and thepublic memorials of the simple shepherdess, who seems to have beencalled from her flocks to change the destiny of France.

title: Zigzag Journeys in Europe: Vacation Rambles in Historic Lands

title: O'er the Atlantic;
author: W[hyte], W[illiam] E.
snippet: From Rouen to this place, and back over a different road to that we w^ent by is a most beautiful drive, and the view from the hill of the country round, including the river Seine and the city, is the most magnificent, and should by all means be seen by strangers visiting Rouen.

title: Highways of travel;
author: Sweat, Margaret J. M.
snippet: I almost felt my Rouen partiality  shaken, as I stood before this admirable union of massive strength and delicate beauty.

title: Highways of travel;
author: Sweat, Margaret J. M.
snippet: Route from Rouen to Paris.

title: Highways of travel;
author: Sweat, Margaret J. M.
snippet: But it is useless to endeavor to do more than enumerate the objects of interest which delight a stranger in Rouen, and beguile him into a longer and yet longer stay among its relics.

title: Highways of travel;
author: Sweat, Margaret J. M.
snippet: Upon the Pont Neuf we see the dark outlines of the fine statue of Pierre Corneillc, the glory of Rouen.

title: Highways of travel;
author: Sweat, Margaret J. M.
snippet: This important matter being finally settled to the satisfaction of one party and the amusement of the other, we mounted into the high omnibus, and rattled  over the old pavements to the Debarcadere of the Havre and Rouen railway.

title: A winter jaunt through historic lands.
author: Stine, Milton H[enry]
snippet: The actual Place is bounded by eight colossal statues typical of the chief towns of France, namely: Lyons, Marseilles, Bordeaux, Nantes, Rouen, Brest, Lille, and Strasburg.

author: Snyder, Marcia Penfield. [from old catalog]

title: Eight lands in eight weeks;
author: Snyder, Marcia Penfield. [from old catalog]
snippet: This is a regular tramping ground of old Gothic builders,  and when one thinks of the shortness of time and the scarcity of money, and then reads over such names as Soissons and Laon, Rouen, Beauvais and Amiens, Caen and Evreux, and their compeers, he is near despair.

title: A summer's jaunt across the water.

title: Five months abroad;
author: Scripps, James E.
snippet: The cathedral of Rouen is a fine specimen of Gothic architecture, very richly ornamented.

title: Five months abroad;
author: Scripps, James E.
snippet: The people all seemed so polite and good natured that we were quite charmed with Rouen.

title: Five months abroad;
author: Scripps, James E.
snippet: We break the journey at Rouen, a large and important place, well built, but interesting  chiefly for several old churches and other buildings which have not been spoiled by modern restoration.

title: Five months abroad;
author: Scripps, James E.
snippet: I therefore  traced out a route embracing Liverpool, London, Antwerp, Brussels, Cologne, Mayence, Frankfort - on - the - Main, Nuremberg, Munich, Innsbruck, Yerona, Venice, Padua, Bologna, Florence, Rome, Pisa, Genoa, Turin, Milan, the Simplon Pass, Martigny, Chamounix, Geneva, Lausanne, Berne, Bale, Strassburg, Paris, Rouen, Dieppe, and so back to England which being a small country and easily covered less required a pre-arranged route.

title: Eight journeys abroad /
author: Rosengarten, Mary D. Richardson
snippet: As we leave on Thursday  for Rouen and Havre he will not have very long with us.

title: Eight journeys abroad /
author: Rosengarten, Mary D. Richardson
snippet: We leave Paris Thursday, 23rd, and stay over night at Rouen and will dine

title: Eight journeys abroad /
author: Rosengarten, Mary D. Richardson
snippet: We are going to make a two-days' trip, to Rheims, Laon, Pierrefonds, Compiegne and Beauvais, when it clears, and will stop at Rouen on our way to Havre, probably leaving here the 23rd.

title: Eight journeys abroad /
author: Rosengarten, Mary D. Richardson
snippet: I suppose you know we have taken staterooms on the Touraine 25th of Sept., and will sail from Havre, stopping at Rouen over one night.

title: Eight journeys abroad /
author: Rosengarten, Mary D. Richardson
snippet: We shall probably be in Paris from Sept. 5th to 23 rd and go on to Havre stopping at Rouen for a day.

title: Eight journeys abroad /
author: Rosengarten, Mary D. Richardson
snippet: Rouen Sept.19,

title: Eight journeys abroad /
author: Rosengarten, Mary D. Richardson
snippet: Journey to Rouen, meeting  there Mrs. Thackara,  daughter of Gen'l Sherman and the interesting  things in

title: Eight journeys abroad /
author: Rosengarten, Mary D. Richardson
snippet: Rouen and Havre were visited in company with Mrs. Thackara, daughter of General Wm.

title: Eight journeys abroad /
author: Rosengarten, Mary D. Richardson
snippet: After the return to Paris, short tours to Fontainebleau, Chantilly, Compiegne, Laon, Rouen and places memorable by their participation in the terrible War of 1914-1916, were made.

title: We four.
author: Rees, L. L.
snippet: But Rouen is only memorable at the present time for two things, — the Cathedral and the monument to Joan of Arc, on the very site where she was so wickedly burned.

title: We four.
author: Rees, L. L.
snippet: From the Hill of St. Catherine, Rouen spreads before us as one of the most picturesque of provincial towns ; but its narrow, dark and dirty streets, with wooden houses faced with slate, cannot add beauty to the picture.

title: Over-sea;
author: Morford, Henry
snippet: Over a flatter and less-interesting country that that of the route from Dieppe and Rouen : by Creil, with its resemblance  to Worcester in Massachusetts ; along whole lines of Rhode Island-ish windmills on the breezy heights , by Longjean, with the whole railway station apparently occupied  by vans of compressed peat made into a species ot cake ; over a low, marshy, crceky, willowy country, approaching Amiens ; to Amiens itself, a fine oM town lying away to the right, with its many-pointed roofs and conical towers, its Cathedral with delicate tracery all around the roof, its fragile,  sharp spire shooting up in the centre, and its memories of a treaty in which nearly all the world was once concerned

title: Over-sea;
author: Morford, Henry
snippet: We were away Paris-ward, again, at last, through two long tunnels that seemed nearly extensive enough for the kissing of the English Box Tunnel or the " turning over a new leaf,' Anglicc, changing the shirt, mentioned in another droll story of those' railway experiences ; through the tunnels and over the Seine, with another glimpse of its sinuous, serpentine beauty, and of the city stretching like a toy-work down the loner, single quay ; and then good-bye to Rouen, relic of the old^and gem on the bright bosom of " My Normandie !"

title: Over-sea;
author: Morford, Henry
snippet: A memorable picture, even as seen through the pipe-ind-cigar-snioke from our carriage windows ; and perhaps  I may have carried away all the pleasanter impressions of the old city of Rouen, from not having taken the liberty of making too close an inspection.

title: Over-sea;
author: Morford, Henry
snippet: But walls and houses, I presume, soon forget the wrongs and outrages which have once riven their stony hearts ; for certainly the good old town of Rouen did not seem to look frowningly even on the incarnate Englishman at my side, either in revenge for the great siege, or the Maid of Orleans, or those later outrages to the French name, summed up in the two words " Waterloo" and " St, Helena."

title: Over-sea;
author: Morford, Henry
snippet: It did not need the exclamations  of my companions to tell me that this was one or the oldest historic cities of France — R .uen, over the name of which so many bad puns have been made by the unscrupulous  — and that the splendid spires at which I looked without  the hope of seeing them nearer, were those of the Cathedral  of Rouen and the fine old church of St. Ouen, the latter said to have one of the handsomost painted windows on the continent.

title: Over-sea;
author: Morford, Henry
snippet: It is above the city, as it is with the Seine when comino- down from the Cote d'Or, by Rouen, and after it leaves contaminating Paris — it is above the city, before it has become the slave of a commerce too large for it — it is as it sweeps placidly down by Windsor and Chertsey Mead, and Walton-on-Thaaies, and Hampton, and Twickenham, and Ptichmond, and Kew, and Brentford, that the Thames, later a thing to despise (and still later a thing to respect) is yet something to love and admire.

title: Travels in lands beyond the sea.
author: Linskill, Charles Dorrance.
snippet: A gentleman said, " Women are not allowed on the streets of Rouen after 8 o'clock in the evening."

title: Travels in lands beyond the sea.
author: Linskill, Charles Dorrance.
snippet: This is Rouen, at three o'clock in the morning, a great city of France, sleeping.

title: Travels in lands beyond the sea.
author: Linskill, Charles Dorrance.
snippet: "The eight fine statues in the square represent the chief towns of France, viz., Lyons, Marseilles, Bordeaux,  Nantes, Rouen, Brest, Lille and Strasburg (now German).

author: Hazlitt, William Carew

title: Over the ocean;
author: Guild, Curtis
snippet: Around the square, at intervals, are eight huge marble statues, seated upon pedestals, which represent eight of the great cities of France, such as Marseilles, Rouen, Lyons, Bordeaux, &c. Each figure is said to face in the direction in which the city or town it is called for lies from Paris.

title: Glances at Europe:
author: Greeley, Horace
snippet: Rouen is interesting for its antiquities, including several venerable and richly adorned Churches which I had no time to visit.

title: Glances at Europe:
author: Greeley, Horace
snippet: Rouen, the capital of ancient Normandy, is the fifth city of France, only Paris, Lyons, Marseilles and Bordeaux having more inhabitants.

title: Glances at Europe:
author: Greeley, Horace
snippet: We left Paris at 8 yesterday morning ; halted at the fine old town of Rouen before noon ; were in Dieppe at 2£ p.

title: Glances at Europe:
author: Greeley, Horace
snippet: The quickest and most usual route from Paris to London  is that by way of Calais and Dover ; but as I had traversed that once, and part of it twice, I resolved to try another for my return, and chose the cheapest and most direct of all — that by way of Rouen, Dieppe, New-Haven and the Brighton Railroad — which is 32 miles shorter than the Calais route, but involves four times as long a watei passage, and so is spun out to more than twice the length of the other.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: We had a deliciouscaneton de Rouen.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: At Rouen, where we passed some days, we had morephotographing of churches — some of the exterior of StOuen were most successful ; in that beautiful church theguide told us he had often been over it with " le fameuxMonsieur Ruskin, un homme bien instruit, mais bien singu-lier!" A more amiably willing and good-tempered manthan my companion has proved himself during the last twoweeks that we have travelled about France together, itwould be hard to find.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: At the end of October I was at Rouen, having determined on beginning a Life of Joan of Arc — it was my thirdvisit to the capital of Normandy, and having an objectmade that third visit even of more interest than earlierones.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: From the Channel Islands I crossed to Normandy,staying a few days at Granville, Rennes and Rouen, afterwards visiting Tours.

title: Ten days abroad;
author: Fuller, Henry Starkey.
snippet: From Paris I should like to have returned by way of Rouen and Normandy — and to have had a passing sight of Chateau Gaillard, the Lion Hearted Richard's gay and rugged Norman castle, of which the rock dungeons still remain; but one cannot see all, even with abundant time at disposal, which I had not.

title: Hospitable England in the seventies;
author: Dana, Richard Henry
snippet: Again I happened  to ride in the carriage with the same English people as from Rouen to Havre.

title: Hospitable England in the seventies;
author: Dana, Richard Henry
snippet: On the train from Rouen to Havre I rode with a nice English gentleman and lady of very quiet manners and dress and much dignity and I saw them again on the steamer.

title: Hospitable England in the seventies;
author: Dana, Richard Henry
snippet: At Rouen went to the Court of Appeals in the early afternoon and heard a sentence of imprisonment  for two years and the beginning of a new suit and the swearing-in of the jury.

title: Hospitable England in the seventies;
author: Dana, Richard Henry
snippet: Left Paris for London by way of Rouen, Havre, and Southampton.

title: A knight templar abroad;
author: Cord, W. Harlan.
snippet: of the price of the Franco-Prussian war in 1870-71), Bordeaux, Nantes, Marseilles, Brest, Rouen, and Lyons, where the Terror raged as madly, almost as in Paris itself.

title: Correspondence of James Fenimore-Cooper /
author: Cooper, James Fenimore
snippet: We shall start on our trip to Germany, after my statue of Comeille has been unveiled at Rouen (in July).

title: Correspondence of James Fenimore-Cooper /
author: Cooper, James Fenimore
snippet: We went by Rouen, Dieppe, Abbeville, Arras, Tourcoing and to Brussells.

title: Correspondence of James Fenimore-Cooper /
author: Cooper, James Fenimore
snippet: We then went to Paris, by the way of Havre and Rouen.

title: Correspondence of James Fenimore-Cooper /
author: Cooper, James Fenimore
snippet: House of Mr. Themeau-fils at Rouen.

title: Correspondence of James Fenimore-Cooper /
author: Cooper, James Fenimore
snippet: I suppose that you will come to-morrow or Saturday at four o'clock, and that you will tell us the day that you wish to see us at Rouen.

title: Correspondence of James Fenimore-Cooper /
author: Cooper, James Fenimore
snippet: Our dear Father bought a travelling caleche at Rouen, and we were soon climbing the hill of St. Catherine, where we greatly enjoyed the fine view.

title: Correspondence of James Fenimore-Cooper /
author: Cooper, James Fenimore
snippet: At Rouen we passed several days under the shadow of the grand old Cathedral, which was a great delight to him, a sublime wonder of architecture.

title: Correspondence of James Fenimore-Cooper /
author: Cooper, James Fenimore
snippet: After a few days we embarked for Rouen in a tugboat.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: One large house, now used as amilitary hospital and called "Argyll's Lodgings"looked exactly as if it had stepped over fromRouen or Angers, or some other town on thebanks of the Seine or the Loire.

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: Over a flatter and less-interesting country that thatof the route from Dieppe and Rouen : by Creil, with its resemblance to Worcester in Massachusetts; along wholelines of Rhode Island-ish windmills on the breezy heights ,by Longjean, with the whole railway station apparently occupied by vans of compressed peat made into a species of cake ;over a low, marshy, creeky, willowy country, approachingAmiens ; to Amiens itself, a fine old town lying away to theright, with its many-pointed roofs and conical towers, itsCathedral with delicate tracery all around the roof, its fragile, sharp spire shooting up in the centre, and its memoriesof a treaty in which nearly all the world was once concerned

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: All this time the Seine has been neglected, just as if wehad not made the acquaintance of the little river, in what theclosely-occupied days make us think almost ages ago, downby that pleasant antique city of Rouen.

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: The second notable thing in Paris was not, as I was aboutto say, the Grand Hotel—rather the se/gens de ville or gendarmerie, of whom I had begun to catch glimpses on therailway stations at Monville and Rouen, but who began to beas prominent a feature in the metropolis, as I had found theliveried and powdered lacqueys of London, hanging aroundSoho Square Bazaar aud the doors of the fashionable shopsou Regent Street, at the hours when their ladies were performing the fashionable duty of afternoon shopping.

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: We were away Paris-ward, again, at last, through two longtunnels that seemed nearly extensive enough for the kissingof the English Box Tunnel or the " turniug overa new leaf,"Anglicc, changing the shirt, mentioned in another droll storyof those railway experiences ; through the tunnels and overthe Seino, with another glimpse of its sinuous, serpentinebeauty, and of the city stretching like a toy-work down thelong, single quay ; and then good-bye to Rouen, relic of theold and gem on the bright bosom of " My Normandie !"Half a dozen other gliirpse3 of the little river, beforedrawing within the roar of the great continental whirlpool—all bright, charming and pastoral, and none of them suggestive of the metropolitan character accorded to a portion of itslength.

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: A memorable picture, even as seen through thepipe-md-cigar-smoke from our carriage windows ; and perhaps I may have carried away all the pleasanter impressionsof the old city of Rouen, from not having taken the liberty ofmaking too close an inspection.

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: minster Abbey having lost its head—whe« I rememberedhim sitting down with his army before this old town in June,1415, fighting for a crown to which he had no more title thanone of the Turkish Sultans could have exhibited—and holding that siege month after month for nearly a year, until allthe horses, dogs, cats, rats and even mice in the city hadbeen devoured by the starving—until fifteen or twenty thousand, many of them helpless men, women and new-born children, had perished in the moats and ditches defending thebeleagured city—until, besides all the havoc made amongthe garrison and population by the casualties of battle anddisease, not less than fifty thousand, of all sexes, ages andconditions, bad died in the actual pangs of starvation !But walls and houses, I presume, soon forget the wrongsand outrages which have once riven their stony hearts ; forcertainly the good old town of Rouen did not seem to lookfrowniugly even on the incarnate Englishman at my side,either in revenge for the great siege, or the Maid of Orleans,or those later outrages to the French name, summed up inthe two words " Waterloo" and " St. Helena."

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: And this belief may hold the longer,I fancy, from the fact that England has not been in the habitof showing extraordinary mercy, either in the late or the farpast, whether in India or in Ireland, to those who fight toolong and well to defend their native land against herpower !But whether Joan of Arc perished there with the cruelfire licking her dainty limbs, or no, certain it is that the oldRouen on which I looked as it lay so peacefully under theSabbath sun that morning had been one of the bones of contention in the long wars of the English Henries ; and that ithad sustained, in one of the dark years for France followingAgincourt, a siege of such cruelty and terror as not evenmore modem and bloodier history can easily parallel.

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: It did not need the ex-clamations of my companions to tell me that this was one oithe oldest historic cities of France—R .uen, over the nameof which so many bad puns have been made by the unscrupulou—and that the splendid spires at which I looked without the hope of seeing them nearer, were those of the Cathedral of Rouen and the fine old church of St. Ouen, the lattersaid to have one of the handsomost painted windows on thecontinent.

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: It is above the city, as it is with the Seine whencoming down from the Cote d'Or, by Rouen, and after itleaves contaminating Paris—it is above the city, before ithas become the slave of a commerce too large for it—it is asit sweeps placidly down by Windsor and Chertsey Mead,and Walton-on-Thames, and Hampton, and Twickenham, andRichmond, and Kew, and Brentford, that the Thames, latera thing to despise (and still later a thing to respect) is yetsomething to love and admire.

title: Travels in Lands beyond the Sea. Beauty and Glory of Western Europe, etc
author: Linskill, Charles D.
snippet: A gentleman said, " Women are not allowedon the streets of Rouen after 8 o'clock in the evening."

title: Travels in Lands beyond the Sea. Beauty and Glory of Western Europe, etc
author: Linskill, Charles D.
snippet: This is Rouen, atthree o'clock in the morning, a great city of France,sleeping.

title: Travels in Lands beyond the Sea. Beauty and Glory of Western Europe, etc
author: Linskill, Charles D.
snippet: FOREST VILLE D' AVRAY BOULEVARD DE LA REINE VERSAILLES A PALACE A FOURTH OF A MILE LONG MAGNIFICENCE BRILLIANT WITH GLORIES COST ONEHUNDRED AND TWENTY-SEVEN MILLION FRANCS * KINGS AND QUEENS PILLARS OF SILVER AMID RAIN-BOWS, BEARING UP CANOPIES OF GOLD—SEVRES' CHINAPALACE SHAKE HANDS ANGELIC GUIDES THEWONDERFUL ROAD, THIRTY-FIVE HUNDRED MILESLONG, RUNNING THROUGH EMPIRES OF WEALTH,LANDS OF MILK AND HONEY, AND KINGDOMS OFBEAUTY AND WONDER THE UNITED STATES GREATIN CITIES AND RAILWAYS NO TATTERED BEGGARS RUSHING THROUGH FRANCE BY MOONLIGHT ROUENSLEEPING DIEPPE BY THE SEA THE SEA DANCES INGREEN AND WHITE SEA SICKNESS—WHITE CLIFFSOF ENGLAND SEEN THROUGH MIST RUSHINGTHROUGH WOODS, ROCKS, MEADOWS AND TOWNS TOLONDON.

title: Travels in Lands beyond the Sea. Beauty and Glory of Western Europe, etc
author: Linskill, Charles D.
snippet: " The eight fine statues in the square represent thechief towns of France, viz., Lyons, Marseilles, Bordeaux, Nantes, Rouen, Brest, Lille and Strasburg (nowGerman).

title: Travels in Lands beyond the Sea. Beauty and Glory of Western Europe, etc
author: Linskill, Charles D.
snippet: field, Birmingham, Leamington, Warwick, Coventry,Stratford-on-Avon, Oxford, London, Canterbury,Dover, Calais, Amiens, Paris, Versailles, Rouen,Dieppe, New Haven, Cardiff, Gloucester, Leicester, Middlesborough, Durham, Berwick, Edinburgh,Queen's Ferry, Dunfermline, Sterling, Glasgow, Greenock, Paisley, Dumfries, Stranraer, Larne, Giant'sCauseway, Portrush, Coleraine, Belfast, Dublin, Chester, etc.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: The country between Rouen and Paris is fertileand well-cultniated, finely undulating, with here andthere a commanding eminence, from which you getsome very extensive and charming views.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: The average rate betweenRouen and Paris, is about seven miles per hour.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: Left Rouen for Paris, June 17th, at 6 o'clock A.M. in the diligence, which, though exceedingly clumsy, as I have already remarked, is as safe, perhaps, asany mode of travelling whatever.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: All the approaches to Rouenare adorned with avenues of noble trees, chiefly elmsand horse-chesnuts.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: In Rouen theyalso show you the statue of the celebrated Maid ofOrleans, whom the English, to their everlasting disgrace, burnt as a witch in 1430.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: Rouen was his native city, and the house inwhich he was bora, on the 6th of June 1606, is stillstanding.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: Rouenis pleasantly situated in tbe midst of a fertile district,on tbe right bank of the Seine.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: Thebare perpendicular rocks—the steep and verdant hillsid—the sudden slope—the deep ravine—the orchard—the forest— the ornamental shade trees, standing inlong rows like the shorn box of our gardens—thesmooth meadow—the busy town—the straw-thatchedand fortuitous hamlet, hidden among the willows—the ancient castle—the vast ranges of cultivated fields,resembling the beds of a boundless garden—theseand such as these are the objects upon which my eyewas continually feasted, from nine in the morning tillhalf past 7 o'clock in the evening, when we arrivedat Rouen.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: On Monday morning I took the boat for Rouen,which lies at the head of steam navigation on the Seine,about seventy miles from its mouth.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: Havre—The Market—The Cote—The Sabbath—Seamen's Chap-el—From Havre to Rouen—Rouen—Public Buildings—Cor-neille—From Rouen to Paris.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: I amquite sure, that I never saw so much in any singleday of my life, as from Rouen to Paris.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: Seamen's Chapel—From Havre to Rouen—Rouen—PublicBuildings—Corneille—From Rouen to Paris.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: These four consisted of a celebrated actorfrom Rouen, then staying in St. Valery, a retiredgentleman, a timber merchant, and the station-master.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: I was much assisted in the carriageat Rouen by a young English gentleman, who in-terpreted what I could not understand, and whothoroughly took my part against the stern railway-official.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: He was for detaining me inRouen until the difference was paid.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: Arriving in Rouen about 4.30,1was to experience some annoyance.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: The only place at which I changedcarriages was Motteville ; with stoppages for refreshments at Rouen and Mantes.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: 10 c. ;to Rouen, 7 fr.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: His body7 was brought from Rouenand laid here in a " feir chest made of stone."

title: Over the Ocean; or, Sights and Scenes in Foreign Lands
author: Guild, Curtis.
snippet: Around thesquare, at intervals, are eight huge marble statues, seatedupon pedestals, which represent eight of the great cities ofFrance, such as Marseilles, Rouen, Lyons, Bordeaux, &c.Each figure is said to face in the direction in which the cityor town it is called for lies from Paris.

title: Observations in Europe, principally in France and Great Britain
author: Durbin, John Price.
snippet: You glide along through verdant meadows, sometimes between chalky cliffs, passing village after village in rapid succession the entiredistance from Rouen to Paris.

title: Observations in Europe, principally in France and Great Britain
author: Durbin, John Price.
snippet: We happened to go from Rouen to Paris in the steamer which had conveyed the remains ofthe Emperor upthe Seine, on their way from St. Helena to the capital.

title: Observations in Europe, principally in France and Great Britain
author: Durbin, John Price.
snippet: Having made the preparations requisite for our departurenext morning, we slept three or four hours, and at fiveo'clock A.M. of the 22d were gliding out of the harbourin a steamer, on our way up the Seine to Rouen.

title: A Knight Templar abroad; or, Reminiscences of travel beyond the sea
author: Cord, W. Harlan.
snippet: It has been disputed that Gutenberg was the inventor of printing, but additional proof of the fact, if anywere needed, which should forever set at rest the vexedquestion, is found in the fact that in the universitylibrary at Rouen there has been recently found a letterwhich bears date of 1470, and tells about the introduction of printing into Paris that year, by three menwho distinctly professed to be apprentices to JohannesGutenberg.

title: A Knight Templar abroad; or, Reminiscences of travel beyond the sea
author: Cord, W. Harlan.
snippet: of the price of the Franco-Prussian war in 1870-71),Bordeaux, Nantes, Marseilles, Brest, Rouen, andLyons, where the Terror raged as madly, almost asin Paris itself.
